p.s: This extract from William Shakespeare's play Macbeth, first performed 1606 in the London Globe Theatre, contains the seventh scene out of the first act.

In that scene Shakespeare describes Macbeth's conviction by his wife Lady Macbeth to kill his King Duncan and therefore fullfilfulfil the prophecy about his future as Scottish kingKing given by three old witches before.
This scene leads towards the decisive point of the play because Macbeth's loyalty to his king is proofenproven very hard.
He needs to decide whether to take action and and try to gain more power or to stay loyal and wait for his fate to come.
That is why that scene is one of the most important ones throughout the play which has its historical base on the fights for the Scottish throne in the eleventh century.
The scene starts with a question from Lady Macbeth who asks why Macbeth already has left the feast even if Duncan is still not ready with his meal.
Macbeth questions whether Duncan has asked for him and his wife gives another question instead of an answer in which she asks Macbeth why he would know that the kingKing havehas not asked for him.

Next, Macbeth states that he would not like to follow their plan anymore to kill the kingKing because Macbeth has already achieved an honor due to his new title, Thane of Cawdor, and he would like to use the situation as it is right now for his benefit.

Lady Macbeth, instead of agreeing on his decision, illustrates that he obviously lost his manliness and hope on the kingship, so that he would still like to achieve the title but not by using shuner strategies.
She shows him that he could reach everything he wants, if he shows steadfastness and that is why he reacts by stating that noone could be more like a man than him.
His wife goes on and examines that only if he will participate in killing Duncan, he will be a real man.
She cannot understand why the visceral appealing situation due to the KingKing in their house and the prophecy does not convince Macbeth to take action.
Hence, she also demonstrates her decisiveness and simply neglects Macbeth's doubts about a possible failure by saying that a failure is possible but must be accepted.
She also states that if Macbeth decides to find his bravery again, thethey will not fail.

Furthermore, she supports her previously named point that the situation is very inciting by explaining how her plan should work and how defenseless Duncan will be during the night, after the chamberlains are drunk.
The scene ends with a whishwish by Macbeth how would like his wife only to give birth to male childrenschildren due to her fearless character.
Additionally, he also sums up his thoughts after his wife's words and explains that he is persuaded to take action, even if he must hide his purpose before Duncan is sleeping.
